tweet.full_text: @CivGame Absolutely! Already preordered  deluxe. Looks like the best Civ yet. Can‚Äôt wait to play. I‚Äôll follow again when twitter spams less.
@CivGame I ‚ù§Ô∏è  you, but I have to unfollow. In the past 35 days, 42% of your tweets are repeats. https://t.co/48yPNQklg1 I'll use reddit üò™

@ashly_burch just finished Horizon Zero Dawn and had no idea it was you until the credits. I've been a HAWP sub for years. :) That's talent!
@Sodapoppintv it‚Äôs okay, we know what it is.
@streamhive hey! Really impressed with your image capturing. I'd love to learn how you're doing it. Do you have a github?
@PlayOverwatch @timthetatman might need to double check that hit reg. The Genji was closer to his crosshair than Lucio.

@iAWriter I LOVE YOU!
@iAWriter how can I re-enable autosave for OS X? On my new MacBook, I have to manually save all files, but on my old one it autosaved them.
@uknowthen your Mafia boss analogy about sending commands and when they return they succeeded or failed made effects finally make sense!
@SorenJohnson The problem isn‚Äôt the new generation. It is that ‚ÄúFirst Pass The Post‚Äù is a broken voting system.
@EdBeach23 could you explain why the machine gun has less range than the archer/field cannons?
@edwardscherf do you think it was intentional or accidental? Is it still shameful if it's an accident?
@antonstrenger how can I get started modding? Is the engine already released?

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm 1. The preview is near instant. While I can‚Äôt control-click a number and slide it around, I can see the effects of numbers *as I type them* so no saving & compiling required.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm The true potential of Swift will be reached with the libraries built on top of it: SwiftUI. For the first time I actually feel an immediate connection to my coding. While it‚Äôs not quite as seamless as @worrydream‚Äôs Inventing on Principle demos, it‚Äôs still magical. So which parts?

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream I don't think I can change your mind, but maybe I can share the story of how mine was. Watching @lexfridman's AI podcast with @clattner_llvm helped me understand what Swift's purpose and its future. For years it's been laying foundations, and unimpressed, many have dismissed it.
@ariaminaei @spiralganglion Mind sharing a GIF of this effect? I tried searching online but couldn‚Äôt find it. Would love to try and replicate.

@jonathoda @worrydream It's unlikely, but I wouldn't say never. Apple has made some surprising moves recently. But even if never does the community is already building OpenSwiftUI & SwiftWebUI. I think the critical piece that will drive adoption is how easy SwiftUI is when coming from React.

@jonathoda It combines the power & safety of Rust with the simplicity of Zig/V. The developer tooling of SwiftUI is better than anything I've ever used, it feels like a @worrydream demo. Many will be hesitant because of its association with Apple, but soon it will stand out on its own.

@jonathoda I'm long on Swift. Just a few weeks ago I was betting on Rust or Zig/V ‚Äî but my appreciation for the complexity of systems/low-level has deepened. With Swift's open-sourcing, running on Windows/Linux/Android, WASM target, I think it is very well positioned to dominate.
That triangle though.
Hey, I wrote this. At one time I thought it would be good to have 2 twitters. Now I don't know which I use for which. But this tweet it about programming. https://t.co/PeABpIbKB2
@steveruizok I absolutely love what you're trying to build here.

@colmtuite Interesting approach making a different palette for both light & dark modes! More work but I can already see how it would simplify the use of each color.

I've been flipping the numbers, eg: light mode _ green.200 ‚Üí dark mode _ green.800. But I like this much more.

12 years. Neat coincidence that @visakanv and I joined Twitter within a day of each other (just 19135 IDs apart) but we use it in a completely different way. It's my most heavily used social media but I don't tweet a lot... ü§î https://t.co/IUtGtyltnw

@CyberpunkGame @YouTube I‚Äôm really surprised there weren‚Äôt any electric ‚ö°Ô∏è cars featured! 

As a @Tesla driver, I definitely think the future is electric. Hoping there will be at least a few ‚ö°Ô∏èüöó in Cyberpunk. I think these cars reflect the current times more than 50 years from now.

@NickMilo I love your distinction between outliners (lists) & writers (prose). It helps me understand why I'm not happy with either one‚Äî I'm looking for an ¬´organizer¬ª, something that's a bit more visual, spatial, data-driven... & moldable. Almost like Notion but more like programming.

@anthilemoon 1. Cognitor ‚Üí I spend most of my time in my head, just thinking.
2. Creator ‚Üí I make some of the things I think about.
3. Consumer ‚Üí I like to absorb as much as possible to inform my thinking & creating.
4. Collector ‚Üí I wish this was automatic; to me note taking is tedious.
RT @felixakiragreen: iPhone Mini is the most I've been excited for a tech gadget in years¬∑ It's hard to contain how thrilled I am ü•≥ using m‚Ä¶
Finally iPhones are getting smaller again. #AppleEvent Love the green.

@visakanv One of the inspirations for the fully zoomed out view is this graphic by @waitbutwhy https://t.co/52bSsWa85C where you can see your whole life, but in weeks. Having this perspective in a TODO app would reframe everything you wanted to get done (in your life).

@visakanv It would also function as a habit tracker‚Äî similar to Apple Watch‚Äôs activity rings. That‚Äôs been the single most powerfully motivating digital system I‚Äôve ever used. Currently rocking a 505 day streak of closing all my rings. I think the magic is how satisfying and pretty it is.

@visakanv I have plans to build this someday‚Äî a todo app that becomes a zoomable life timeline. (When I‚Äôm done working on my current project, so maybe like a year.) I‚Äôd love to collaborate with you if it doesn‚Äôt already exist.

@SorenJohnson @sid_meier @SidMeiersMemoir @CivGame this is how I feel about not being able to automate builders anymore. Ruined the game for me, because I like playing wide. Having to manually build hundreds of workers & thousands of improvements just killed my love for the game. üò¢ I‚Äôve shared this feedback many times.
@visakanv I need to do this as well.
@markopolojarvi Like moving to EU or Canada. Don‚Äôt know if we can handle another 4 years.
@geo_spatialist Stunning! I would love to 3D print this. Would pay for the STL!

@thesephist üòê I‚Äôm guilty of this. But I think it‚Äôs because I don‚Äôt have a better word‚Ä¶ but I just love all kinds of systems: metric, design, operating, personal habit, networks, modeling, programming, ‚Ä¶ and building them is my favorite.

I absolutely love the feel of the iPhone Mini in my hand. The hard edges and smaller size ü§© ‚Ä¶ it could even go a bit smaller (like the 4) but I‚Äôll take whatever I can get. Thanks @apple & @tim_cook for making a small phone again!

@thesephist I love this so much. Currently working on my own system. You‚Äôve made some incredible things here! It‚Äôs really interesting to me how similar many of our needs are- and because there aren‚Äôt solutions out there we just need to make it ourselves.

I don't understand how come the "Add another tweet" button is here on my own tweets, but not on my other tweets when I'm replying to people.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm PS. In my list of examples I forgot to include Swift Playgrounds which I‚Äôm confident was directly inspired by Bret Victor. I used it myself briefly to learn some of the more basic concepts of Swift ‚Äî though after about an hour I moved into Xcode to start building apps.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm You mentioned atrocious compile times, but I‚Äôm used to clean Gatsby builds taking 3-15 min. So being able to compile & run my app in <30 sec is amazing. But if I can get an instant preview of how it looks (and behaves!) then I don‚Äôt really care about super fast compilation.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm I tried to learn Objective-C about 10 years ago & though I did finish a small app I never made any more because of the difficulty. It was easier & quicker to make websites.

Same reason I like SwiftUI ‚Äî it lets me make more beautiful things with much less code in much less time.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm I think the biggest benefit of React is that it‚Äôs an easy model to learn for building complicated web apps. *I* think it was an inspired move to make SwiftUI work like React because look how popular React is. All those developers will be able to write a SwiftUI app in no time.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm The podcast inspired me to check out the latest WWDC videos on SwiftUI and I was blown away. Not only is it  easier to learn than React, but it completely takes care of the hardest parts like state & lifecycle management, rich user interactions, and complex animations.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm My Swift journey started a few weeks ago after spending months struggling to get some rich interactions & animations working in React Native. While I did get them working, they were buggy and took far too much time & code. It was not sustainable.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm My background is in web development‚Äî so what you call "one of the worst languages ever created" is the bulk of my programming experience. For some more context, in my day job I primarily write TypeScript using Node, React, & Gatsby.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm Thank you for your reply üôè It was very informative & I must admit that I don‚Äôt know much about Swift at all. I didn‚Äôt know about the similarities with SmallTalk, however I have only ever read very positive things about it, so I find it encouraging that Swift is copying them.
One more just to see if it works. Clicking one by one, replying to each one was too much.
I want to test I can create a multi-tweet thread in a single reply this way.
https://t.co/f140DniN0j

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm I‚Äôm sure there are a few more, but those are the ones that stood out to me. I started taking taking screenshots & recordings to show you the side by side, but I already spent 30 minutes writing this so‚Ä¶ here you go.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm 4. Viewing many states simultaneously. While I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs possible to spread time out visually yet, what is more useful to me is that with multiple previews using varying environments, states, & test data I can immediately see the effects of my changes across all of them.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm 3. Connection between code & preview. I can click on elements in the preview and it takes me directly to the code. And inversely, wherever my text cursor is, the corresponding element in preview is highlighted.

@mpweiher @jonathoda @worrydream @lexfridman @clattner_llvm 2. The autocomplete is super helpful. While I can‚Äôt preview the effects before I hit enter, it‚Äôs like 50% less code I have to write, and I love being able to see what are the options available to me. (Granted TypeScript also has this.)
Which animation do you like more? (See the animations in thread)
@jsngr Kind of annoying how we‚Äôre supposed to follow HIG, so that apps ‚Äúlook‚Äù like an iOS app, but not exactly like any system app. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@juvoni Wow this is incredible! Thank you üôè for sharing. The similarities between our systems are striking, mine is just much less developed and organized.

@m_ashcroft That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not using them for my insomnia. Case in point: J Peterson got addicted and had to withdraw in a medical coma. Short term solutions ‚â† real (sustainable) solutions.

I learned so much more by seeing how it was done well than by fumbling through it blindly by myself. Without your code it might have taken me months to make & learn what I was able to in just a week. It's been such an exciting & I know it's only the beginning.

I want to thank you üôè so much for open-sourcing your code. I've spent many hours on your Github, reading code & studying the evolution of your projects. (Mine is also open: https://t.co/0uZC4ordAG ‚Äî if you want to run it you'll need Xcode and there are a few minor bugs ;)

I‚Äôm currently working on turning the blocks into hexagons and next I'm adding animation. (I really like your Apparatus Assembly animations, but for these I‚Äôm going for more of a Matrix digital rain look.)

As my proficiency develops, I have been setting myself more ambitious challenges. Inspired by your Apparatus project I reimplemented the generator in Swift. Then I added more things like corner rounding, seed control, and a palette builder.

@codexeditor the actual drawing is quite similar (path to x, y) but the magic happens one level up (paths ‚Üí shape). a shape can know it's own size, this lets me stretch the hexagons to fill space.

the main reason it would have been so complicated on web is because I have to draw the paths in order to get the hexagonal shapes I want

css can't do this, so I'm left with svg ‚Äî and that's a pain to animate & make interactive

oh yeah AND it took me about an hour to code AND never once was anything undefined

maybe I‚Äôm just bad at web but this would have taken me 10x longer, performed 10x worse, and been 10x harder to animate

having more fun exploring‚Ä¶ 

#SwiftUI continues to ü§Ø amaze me with its power & elegance. 

all of this is <300 lines, no deps, just a few of my own hexagonal helpers. environmentally styled, instant preview, and animation perfection.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda Parametric themes ‚Üí every dimension, color, font, &c should be derived from context or theme. Design systems + tokens start to approach this idea but have only gotten started. Their problem is that they require setting these up before hand.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda Parametry also unlocks adaptive UI‚Äî right now we have to manually program how a UI behaves responsively. When what should happen is it should react to its context and display itself accordingly. It should go, ‚Äúoh I don‚Äôt have enough room here, let me become smaller‚Äù. By itself.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda Parametric constraints ‚Üí this idea is so powerful and fundamental. No interface should ever be statically defined. Your example demonstrated this exactly. In fact, I feel so strongly against static definitions, I feel it so backwards, I'd rather draw on paper than digital.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda Visual ‚Üí because interfaces are visual they ought to be programmed so. Example: imagine telling an architect they needed to write code describing their building instead of drawing it. It‚Äôs üçå. Ideally UI should be visual, state should be state-diagrammed, & the rest coded.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda That‚Äôs the basic idea! Overall it can be simplified into a few core ideas. (And I want to note: none of these ideas are new or mine, they‚Äôre primarily cross-pollination.)

I‚Äôll speak in the abstract and then try to give some concrete examples...
@rikarends @jonathoda I agree with a 15 years of programming UIs. Just started learning CAD + parametric & constraint based modeling and it‚Äôs much closer to how I wish programming UIs was.

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda @OskSta In the future, interfaces will become much more game-like: rich, fluid, adaptive, dynamic, continuously evolving & changing, infinitely & instantaneously customizable. We think we have these already, but interfaces are still in their infancy. (They‚Äôre still limited to screens!)

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda In a way, most of CAD is procedural: the user inputs & from it the computer generates the physical model. Another example is a game called Townscaper by @OskSta ‚Äî he has programmed a set of constraints & as the user clicks away a beautiful town emerges w/ near infinite variation.

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda Yes! Procedural generation is critical. I think the role of ‚Äúhuman designers‚Äù needs to move a layer up the abstraction tree ‚Äî we should be doing less ‚Äúinterface design‚Äù and more ‚Äúsystems design‚Äù. We create the procedure for the design, not the design itself.
@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda I couldn't agree with you more!
@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda This is great advice, thank you. üôè

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda I developed this idea before GPT-3 and had left the "generation" part of unsolved (cathedral-thinking, we'll solve it when we get to it). Then as the code/interface generation demos started to pop up, it just clicked into place.

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda Which is why it needs to be universal. A "CAD-UI" that can design any digital interface, for any platform, any size, any style, and generate the needed code in any language. Then it will be able to transcend the development environment.
@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda üôè Thanks! It's what I intend to my 30s working on.

@rikarends @Lukas_Vision11 @jonathoda You're right - there have been attempts that have fallen short. It's an incredibly hard problem, but I don't believe it's impossible. I like the metaphor of "reusable üöÄ" ‚Äî before SpaceX it didn't work. But the idea was still worth pursuing‚Äî it is the future.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda There are so many lessons to be learned just from CAD (because they‚Äôve been doing it for 60 years). @j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda This is just scratching the surface.

I‚Äôm a designer that learned how to program because no one could make my interfaces the way I wanted them. So now I‚Äôve spent 15 years programming interfaces and I think that‚Äôs wrong. I shouldn‚Äôt be doing this.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda Timeline ‚Üí in CAD the user can jump back in time, make a change, and then jump forward to see it reflected throughout the entire system. Changes can be reordered to apply them differently. This is another super power of CAD that I think has to be felt to appreciate it.

@j_KN0X @rikarends @jonathoda In CAD you can start sketching your object, and then as you build it, reference previous values, and then as common ones emerge define them to be used globally. Then whenever these are updated, everything updates perfectly.
